content: amanda s tunisian waistcoat finished size 42 edge to edge yarn 10 w p i approximately uk aran weight my waistcoat used 260g so if you were to buy or spin 6 or 7 50g balls in a selection of colours you should have plenty of yarn gauge 12 stitches vertical loops and 26 row 13 double row to 4 10cm suggested hook size 6 5/7mm - work starting chain and increase chains with a 5mm hook worked throughout in basic tunisian stitch the stripe pattern is created by working every row in a different colour i e pick up the loops in one colour work them off on the next row in a different colour if you don t make the gaps between colour repeats too long you can eliminate some of the ends needing to be sewn in by stranding the yarn up the edge for a little way always work off the last stitch with the colour wanted for the next row that way the starting loop will be in the correct colour edgings in crab stitch double_crochet worked from left to right the pattern starting at the left side centre front chain 30 work 21 row increasing a stitch work into both front and back of last loop on every pick-up row 41sts chain 11 at the end of the next pick-up row and pick up an extra loop in each chain stitch this is the increase in the neck shaping to bring you up to the shoulder - 52sts work 30 row decreasing 1 stitch every 10 row work through two vertical loops at once for the shoulder slope 49sts next pick-up row pick up only 25 stitches and work straight for a further 21 row the armhole chain 24 stitches at the end of the next pick-up row and work an extra vertical loop in each chain 49sts work 30 row increasing 1 stitch every 10 row for shoulder shaping 52sts work 21 row straight to centre back ** now work the pattern in reverse for the right hand side** to make up the waistcoat pin out the piece on a flat surface and hold a steaming iron over it for a few minutes keep the iron moving and hold it just clear of the fabric - leave to dry sew up the shoulder seams and work crab stitch around the edges to make a button loop make a few chain stitches between the crab stitches in the last stitch of the neck edge and the first stitch of the right front 4 chain is just enough for a 1 button 8 4 ¾ 4 9 17 4 17 ½ 3 ½ 18 8 21 © amanda hannaford 2009
